title: Ticket #3196: SPOOL is wrong with multiple schedds
description: John Wiegand at Fermi noticed a bug in Condor when multiple schedds are defined. See the initial message, reply, and simple demonstration of the bug.
remarks:
2012-Aug-21 22:40:22 by nwp:
The easy solution is to eliminate the default value of JOB_QUEUE_LOG in the param table (that is, revert 395c915).

Or, is it envisioned that something like the following is supposed to work? 

SCHEDD.xxyyz.SPOOL=/foo
SCHEDD.yywwt.SPOOL=/foo2
JOB_QUEUE_LOG=$(SPOOL)/bar
Then JOB_QUEUE_LOG evaluates to /foo/bar for schedd xxyyz and to /foo2/bar for schedd yywwt.

What is the downside of a simple revert?

2012-Aug-22 08:37:11 by tstclair:
From what I recollect about the param system, the above is not possible in some cases.

Thus the only solution that is valid is removal from the param table.

2012-Aug-22 09:38:52 by nwp:
I am setting this to review for Greg T, since Greg put this in the param table in the first place.

2012-Sep-12 13:42:06 by nwp:
Let's get some wisdom written down on this topic. For concreteness, lets consider an example from a configuration file. 
LOCAL_DIR= /scratch/nwp/personal-condor
SPOOL= $(LOCAL_DIR)/spool
SCHEDD.SCHEDDJOBS2.SCHEDD_NAME   = schedd_jobs2
SCHEDD.SCHEDDJOBS2.SCHEDD_LOG    = $(LOG)/SchedLog.$(SCHEDD.SCHEDDJOBS2.SCHEDD_NAME)
SCHEDD.SCHEDDJOBS2.LOCAL_DIR = $(LOCAL_DIR)/$(SCHEDD.SCHEDDJOBS2.SCHEDD_NAME)
SCHEDD.SCHEDDJOBS2.SPOOL = $(SCHEDD.SCHEDDJOBS2.LOCAL_DIR)/spool
I think this configuration is enough to show what is involved.

At this point in the code, there are two ways to look up a configuration/param macro. The code either calls param and associated param_*; functions, or it can call lookup_macro. Now, with the configuration above, what happens?

Let's assume we are in the schedd, with a local-name set to SCHEDDJOBS2. When the code calls param("LOCAL_DIR"), param first tries to lookup "SCHEDD.SCHEDDJOBS2.LOCAL_DIR", then "SCHEDD.LOCAL_DIR", then "LOCAL_DIR". Of course the first lookup succeeds (and the other two are not looked up), and param will find "$(LOCAL_DIR)/$(SCHEDD.SCHEDDJOBS2.SCHEDD_NAME)". Then param calls lookup_macro. The lookup_macro code does not try to scope the LOCAL_DIR on the right-hand side, so it returns "/scratch/nwp/personal-condor", and it looks up "SCHEDD.SCHEDDJOBS2.SCHEDDNAME", to get "schedd_jobs2". So param("LOCAL_DIR") returns "/scratch/nwp/personal-condor/schedd_jobs2" and lookup_macro("LOCAL_DIR") returns "/scratch/nwp/personal-condor".

I tried to simply add the param scoping behavior into lookup_macro, but I just got into an infinite loop, since the code kept expanding SCHEDD.SCHEDDJOBS2.LOCAL_DIR over and over; essentially, the code was trying to figure out what 

SCHEDD.SCHEDDJOBS2.LOCAL_DIR = $(SCHEDD.SCHEDDJOBS2.LOCAL_DIR)/$(SCHEDD.SCHEDDJOBS2.SCHEDD_NAME)
means; on its face, it is not clear what is the meaning; so I stopped working on it.
